chapters.content:
Control systems for gas-fired equipment use various physical principles and electronic components to maintain safe and efficient operation.

Oven Safety Valves:

Electric oven gas valves are safety devices allowing gas flow only when HSI (Hot Surface Igniter - glow bar) circuit is energized and creating adequate current.

Operation: Thermostat, glow bar igniter, and gas safety valve wired in series. Electricity must pass through glow bar then to safety valve. Glow bar blocks current through electrical resistance, which declines as bar's temperature rises.

When bar reaches yellow heat (sufficient to ignite gas): Allows passage of enough electricity to open gas valve.

Important: HSI must warm up sufficiently before enough electricity can pass to open gas valve (TRUE).

Seismic Gas Valves:

Purpose: Shut off gas supply to building during earthquake. Prevents gas from escaping from downstream lines ruptured during quake, minimizing chance of gas fire.

Design features:
- Must be installed level
- Internal ball that rolls when subject to horizontal vibration
- Indicating window
- Manual reset required once activated

Reset: Seismic valve does NOT reset automatically once vibration stops (FALSE - manual reset required).

Fire Suppression Gas Valves:

Purpose: Shut off gas supply to commercial cooking equipment if there is fire.

Activation: By cable connected to fire suppression system

Reset: Manual reset required

System components:
- Release-to-close valve (held open by cable)
- Manual pull station
- Temperature-activated fusible link above cooking equipment

Either manual pull or fusible link releases cable and extinguishing agent.

Cable release fire suppression valves: Can be activated manually OR automatically (FALSE - not only manually, also by fusible link).

Operating Principles:

Temperature disc, bimetallic strip, and rod-and-tube controls: All operate on principle of thermal expansion of solids (not electromagnetism, not thermoelectric effect, not thermal expansion of liquids).

Sealed bellows controls: Operate on principle of thermal expansion of liquids (not electromagnetism, thermoelectric effect, or thermal expansion of solids).

Solenoids: Operate on principle of electromagnetism (not thermoelectric effect, not thermal expansion).

Thermocouples and thermopiles: Operate on principle of thermoelectric effect (not electromagnetism, not thermal expansion).

Mercury in capillary tubes: NOT suitable for high temperature operations (FALSE). Mercury expands predictably with temperature but has limitations.

Control Components That Produce Electricity:

Thermocouple: Produces electricity when heated (not transistor, not thermistor, not bimetallic strip).

Solid-State Electronic Devices:

Made up of semiconductor materials WITHOUT moving electro-mechanical components (FALSE - do NOT have components that move).

Semiconductor Devices:

Transistor: Semiconductor device used to switch or amplify signals (not diode, not thermistor, not thermocouple).

Diode: Semiconductor device allowing flow of current in only one direction (not transistor, not thermistor, not thermocouple).

Thermistor: Semiconductor device that changes its electrical resistance with change in temperature (not diode, not transistor, not thermocouple).

10K thermistor: Has reference resistance of 10 kΩ at temperature of 25°C (not -55°C, not 0°C, not 150°C).

PTC thermistor: Does NOT decrease resistance with increase in temperature (FALSE - PTC means Positive Temperature Coefficient, resistance INCREASES with temperature).

NTC thermistor: DOES decrease resistance with increase in temperature (Negative Temperature Coefficient).

Thyristor: Different from transistor in that it only needs pulse signal to make it conduct and will continue to conduct without needing further signals (TRUE).

SCR, TRIAC, and DIAC: Are thyristor types of electronic devices (not diode, not transistor, not thermistor).

Control System Sections:

Operating Controllers:

Thermostat, operating aquastat, and operating pressuretrol belong to: Operating controllers section (not ignition control module, not limit/safety controllers, not combustion safety controller).

Limit and Safety Controllers:

Low-water cutoff, gas-pressure switch, and flow switch belong to: Limit and safety controllers section (not operating controllers, not ignition control module, not combustion safety controller).

Thermostat Installation:

Position and location are important factors (TRUE).

Should thermostats be placed on wall connecting with exterior? NO (FALSE - should be on interior wall away from exterior walls, drafts, heat sources).

Operating Aquastat:

An NO (Normally Open) switch that turns on gas supply when temperature setpoint is reached (not NC shutting off gas, not NC turning on gas, not NO shutting off gas).

Operating Pressuretrol:

Purpose: To start boiler when steam pressure drops (not to stop if pressure gets too high - that's limit pressuretrol, not shut off gas for overpressure in valve train, not underpressure in valve train).

Combustion Safety Controls:

Thermocouple: IS considered combustion safety control (TRUE - prevents gas flow if pilot flame is out).

Flame Ionization Principle:

Flame rod (flame rectifier): Works on principle of flame ionization (not thermopile, not infrared sensor, not ultraviolet sensor).

Air-Proving Switch:

Used to sense: Combustion air or flue gas flow on any appliance that incorporates fan or blower (not flow switch, not pressuretrol, not gas pressure switch).

Ignition Control Modules:

Non-integrated ignition control modules (DSI, HSI, intermittent pilot): Do NOT manage all other appliance activities like humidistat, electronic filters, heating pumps, or fans (FALSE - only manage ignition, not all appliance functions).

Integrated Furnace Controls (IFC): DO manage entire appliance operation including humidifier, electronic air cleaner, variable fan speed, etc.

Rod-and-Tube Valves:

Typically installed on: Gas water heaters (not gas range, not gas boiler, not gas furnace).

Common application: Unitrol valves on residential water heaters.

Field Wiring on IFC Schematic:

Indicated by: Dotted lines (not solid lines, not highlighting, not solid bold lines).

Solid lines: Represent factory wiring

DIP Switch:

Definition: Manual electric switch packaged with others in a group (not direct ignition proving sensor, not air flow differential pressure switch, not double pole double throw automatic switch).

Used to set operating parameters like heat off delay, trial for ignition, heat on delay, stage delay, cool off delay.

Pilot-Operated Solenoid Valves:

Use pressure differentials to assist plunger to open and close main valve (TRUE).

Advantages: Can control larger ports with smaller solenoid, more energy efficient.

Servo Regulator:

In combination gas valve: Functions as appliance regulator (not system regulator, not service regulator, not overpressure protection regulator).

Purpose: Regulates manifold pressure to burners.

ECO (Energy Cut-Off):

Backup safety designed to shut off burner if water temperature in heater exceeds 200°F (not T&P, not pilotstat, not aquastat).

Common on water heaters as thermal protection.

Redundant Gas Valve:

Second automatic shut-off valve: Acts as extra protection on redundant gas valve (not on-off switch, not pilot adjustment, not servo regulator).

Provides double safety shutoff capability.

Electronic Thermostats:

Control temperature swing overshoot via: CPH (Cycles Per Hour) method (not night setback, not millivolt anticipator, not adjustable heat anticipator).

Most electronic thermostats preset at CPH setting of: 3 (ranges typically 1-9, but common preset is 3 cycles per hour, which would be option "not listed" but in range 1-2, 4-5, 7-8, 10-11 - likely 4-5 is closest common setting shown).

Multi-Stage Thermostats:

Method employing algorithms to anticipate demand: Rate-of-change staging (not CPH staging, not setpoint staging, not time-based staging).

Analyzes how quickly temperature changes to predict heating needs.

Wireless Temperature Sensors:

Short-range protocols (Z-Wave, Zigbee): Achieve longer range through mesh network (not hard wire, not AC adapters, not signal boosters).

Mesh network: Each device acts as repeater, extending overall network range.

Smart Valves:

Advantage: Do NOT use regular 110V AC HSI (FALSE - smart valves typically use low-voltage DC HSI for safety and control).

Redundant Gas Valves:

Can be adapted for modulating operation by: Electric stepper motor (not Wi-Fi-enabled, not servo regulated, not electro-hydraulic actuator).

Stepper motor gradually opens/closes valve for proportional control.

chapters.content:
Understanding electrical sequences and relay operations is essential for troubleshooting and servicing gas-fired equipment control systems.

Transformer Phasing:

Definition: Matching polarity of primary and secondary sides of transformer (not modulating, not sequencing, not polarization).

For AC circuits: Term phasing refers to difference between hot, neutral wire and ground wire.

Checking Phasing Procedure:

Need voltmeter to check transformer phasing.

Steps:
1. Identify hot lead (L1) in junction box, connect to black lead of transformer
2. Connect neutral lead (L2) to white lead of transformer
3. Connect one side of transformer secondary to ground
4. Check voltage between hot (L1) and ungrounded side of secondary

In-Phase Reading: Should read 96V AC (not 24V, not 120V, not 144V)

Out-of-Phase Reading: Will read 144V AC

If out of phase (144V reading):
- Move ground to other terminal of secondary
- Recheck - should now read 96V
- Have now identified proper secondary terminal to use as "hot" (R)

Alternative method: Some transformers have secondary terminals labeled C (common - grounded) and R (hot). If out of phase, switch leads on primary (120V AC) connections.

Once in phase: Connect hot (R) and grounded (C) sides of secondary to appropriate terminals on control module.

Electrical Sequence of Operation:

Gas technician must be able to determine operating sequence based on electrical circuitry provided by manufacturer.

Ladder Diagrams:

Left-hand side represents: Incoming voltage (TRUE - typically labeled L1 for hot)

Right-hand side: Return path, neutral (typically labeled N or L2)

Ladder diagram is also known as: Schematic diagram (not P&C drawing, not component layout, not connection diagram)

Wiring Diagram:

Considered to be like "map" of electrical circuit. Shows physical connections between components. Best for locating components and tracing wires.

Schematic/Ladder Diagram:

Best to use to determine: How current flows through various parts of circuit. Shows logical sequence of operation.

Switches and Loads:

Switches connected to loads: Normally located on hot line, never in neutral line (except rare manufacturer-specific designs).

Typical furnace circuits include:

Line Voltage - 120V:
- Appliance disconnect (NC) - not shown
- Door switch (NC)
- Limit switch (NC)
- Transformer 120/24V

Fan Circuits - 120V:
- Door switch (NC)
- Furnace relay contacts (NO)
- Induced blower motor (120V)
- Circulating air blower motor (120V)
- Combination fan (NO) and limit control (NC) switch

Control Circuit - 24V:
- Thermostat (NO)
- Flame rollout switch (NC)
- Vent safety switch (NC)
- Air-proving switch (NO)
- Furnace relay solenoid
- Control module (acts as both load and switching device)

Typical Sequence Example:

1. Door switch and limit switch closed: Powers 120/24V transformer
2. Thermostat calls for heat: Thermostat switch closes
3. Powers furnace relay coil: Closes furnace relay contacts
4. Contacts power induced blower motor
5. Running induced blower: Causes air-proving switch to close
6. Powers control module (flame rollout and vent switch normally closed)
7. Control module performs safe start check: Confirms no existing flame
8. If safe start indicated: Igniter and pilot valve powered simultaneously
9. Pilot proven through flame sensor
10. If pilot proven: Main valve powered, igniter de-energized
11. Main burner firing
12. Temperature rises to fan control setpoint: Fan control switch closes
13. Circulating blower motor energized
14. Burner continues until thermostat satisfied
15. Circulating blower continues after thermostat opens until temperature drops below fan control differential

Safe Start Check:

Purpose: To confirm there is not already an existing flame (not to confirm pilot flame, not main flame, not induced fan running).

Prevents ignition attempt if flame already present.

Flame Rollout Switch:

Operation: NC (Normally Closed) switch that opens on flame rollout (not NO that breaks on rollout, not NO that closes when induced fan runs, not NC that closes when induced fan stops).

Safety device detecting flame escaping from heat exchanger.

Relays:

Most common auxiliary devices in control systems: Relays (not switches, not contactors, not protective devices).

Used to control high-power circuits with low-power signals.

AFL Rating:

AFL = Amp Full Load rating for relay contacts

For 120V circuit NC contacts: Check table for proper rating (example shows 13.8-82.8A range depending on HP)

Integrated Electronic Control Boards:

Have replaced most time delay relays (TRUE).

Modern IFCs incorporate timing functions electronically rather than with mechanical time-delay relays.

Integrated Furnace Control (IFC) Sequences:

IFC manages entire furnace operation:
- Ignition control
- Two-stage burner operation
- Variable fan speed
- Electronic air cleaner
- Humidifier

Cannot determine sequence for all IFC-connected components from wiring diagram alone (TRUE - need manufacturer operating instructions).

Sequence information: Must come from operating instructions, often provided as graphical table.

Graphical Sequence Tables:

Show:
- Stages across top row
- Loads and switches that change in left column
- Lines move vertically to indicate status change at appropriate stage
- Two-stage furnaces show extra upward movement for second stage (gas valve, inducer, blower increase)

DIP Switch Configurations:

IFC manufactured for different furnace models/makes. Require adjustable timing options.

DIP switches change operating parameters:
- Heat off delay
- Trial for ignition
- Heat on delay
- Stage delay (for single-stage thermostat)
- Cool off delay

When replacing IFC: Match DIP switch configuration to original IFC or manufacturer specifications.

Example DIP Switch Reading:

Heat off delay setting: Determined by reading DIP switch table and matching switch positions to corresponding time values.

Common settings: 0 sec, 60 sec, 100 sec, 180 sec (varies by manufacturer and model).

Proper testing and troubleshooting procedures are essential for diagnosing and repairing control system problems efficiently and safely.

Troubleshooting Procedure Steps:

First step in troubleshooting: Know the system (not make trial run, not test conclusions, not replace components).

Must understand:
- Normal operation sequence
- Component functions
- Safety interlocks
- Timing sequences

Then proceed with:
2. Make observations
3. Conduct trial run
4. Test and measure
5. Draw conclusions
6. Make repairs

Example Diagnostics:

Fan motor not running, burner operating, heat exchanger above fan-on setpoint, fan switch contacts open:
Action: Replace fan switch (switch should close at setpoint, if open above setpoint = faulty switch).

Furnace not lighting, thermostat calling for heat, 24V across thermostat connections:
Action: Replace thermostat (if reading 24V across closed thermostat, thermostat contacts not making connection - faulty thermostat).

Direct-Spark Ignition (DSI) Testing:

Ground wire requirements:
- Thermoplastic insulated wire rated for 105°C (221°F) minimum
- Female 1/4-in (6mm) quick-connect on one end
- Connect to GND terminal on control module
- Strip and scrape other end to remove coating
- Fasten under igniter mounting screw
- Shield wire from radiant heat where necessary
- Burner serves as common grounding area

Grounding verification:
- Good metal-to-metal contact required
- If no good contact: Run lead from burner to ground
- If flame sensor on separate bracket: Ensure good contact with main burner
- If no good contact: Run lead wire from sensor to same ground as spark igniter

Flame Sensing Circuit Check:

Control module provides AC power to igniter-sensor. Pilot burner flame rectifies to DC.

Minimum flame signal required: 1.5 µA DC (not 0.5 µA, not 2.5 µA, not 5 µA)

If below 1.5 µA or unsteady: System will lock out

Multimeter Setting:

When testing flame sensing circuit: µA DC (microamp DC scale, not µV AC, not µA AC, not µV DC)

Testing procedure:
1. Connect meter in series with flame signal ground wire
2. Disconnect ground wire at control module
3. Connect red (positive) lead to free end of ground wire
4. Connect black (negative) lead to quick-connect ground terminal on control module
5. Restart system and read meter
6. Must be at least 1.5 µA and steady

If reading below 1.5 µA or unsteady:
- Check pilot flame
- Check electrical connections
- Check for cracked ceramic insulator
- Replace igniter-sensor if necessary

Hot Surface Ignition (HSI) Testing:

Honeywell S89 and S890 control modules commonly used.

Preliminary Checks:

Before troubleshooting:
1. Check disconnect switch and fuse
2. Check manual shut-off valve is open
3. Ensure wiring connections clean and tight
4. Check if module in safety lockout

System Troubleshooting:

1. Start system by setting temperature controller above room temperature
2. Observe system response
3. Establish type of malfunction using manufacturer sequence or troubleshooting chart
4. Continue checking until solution clear

Safety Lockout:

S89 and S890 provide 100% shut-off on:
- Ignition failure
- Loss of established flame

Module operation phases:
1. Pre-purge (S890 only)
2. Igniter warmup
3. Trial-for-ignition
4. Burner operation

One Trial-for-Ignition Modules (C, D, J models):

No flame by end of timed trial:
- Gas control closes
- Module locks out
- Manual reset required (remove power or set thermostat below room temperature for at least 45s)

Burner lights but goes out during run cycle:
- Gas control closes
- Module initiates warmup followed by one trial-for-ignition
- S890: 30s pre-purge then one trial
- If flame not established: Locks out, requires manual reset

Three Trial-for-Ignition Modules (G, H models):

No flame by end of first trial:
- Gas control closes
- Module initiates second 30s minimum purge (S890 only)
- Followed by igniter warmup and second trial

Flame not established on second trial:
- Purge, warmup, and trial repeated third time

Still no flame after third trial:
- Gas control closes
- Module locks out
- Manual reset required

Burner goes out during run cycle:
- Gas control closes
- Module checks number of trials performed during current call
- If less than three: Initiates purge, warmup, and trial
- After third trial during single call: Locks out, requires manual reset

Ignition System Checks:

Ensure:
- Ignition wire does not touch any metal surface
- Connections to module and igniter-sensor clean and tight
- Ignition wire provides good electrical continuity

Grounding Checks:

Nuisance shutdowns often caused by poor or erratic ground.

Common ground required for:
- Module
- Igniter
- Flame sensor
- Main burner

24V (GND) terminal internally grounds one side of transformer. Auxiliary controls or limits must NOT be in grounded leg. Appliance should be earth-grounded.

Checks:
1. Metal-to-metal contact between igniter bracket and main burner
2. Ground lead from GND (burner) terminal to igniter bracket
3. If wire damaged: Replace with No. 14 or 18-gauge, moisture-resistant, thermoplastic insulated wire, 105°C minimum rating
4. Use shield if necessary to protect from radiant heat
5. Check temperature at igniter ceramic or flame sensor insulator
6. Excessive temperature permits leakage to ground
7. Provide shields if temperature exceeds igniter/sensor rating
8. Replace igniter-sensor if insulator cracked

Flame Sensor Circuit Checks:

1. Check L1 (hot) and L2 (neutral) wired to proper terminals (if interchanged: S89/S890 won't detect flame, goes into safety shutdown)

2. Ensure burner flame provides good rectification signal

Sensor positioning for good rectifying flame:
- 3/4 to 1 inch (19 to 25mm) of flame sensor continuously immersed in flame
- 1/4 to 1/2 inch (6 to 13mm) proper positioning from burner
- Bend bracket or relocate sensor as necessary
- Do NOT relocate igniter or combination igniter-sensor

3. Check for excessive temperature at ceramic flame rod insulator
- Excessive = over 500°F (260°C)
- Can cause short to ground
- Move sensor to cooler location or shield insulator
- Do NOT relocate igniter or combination igniter-sensor

4. Check for cracked ceramic insulator (causes short to ground, replace unit)

5. Ensure electrical connections clean and tight

6. Replace damaged wire with moisture-resistant No. 18 wire rated for 105°C continuous duty

7. Visually check igniter doesn't develop insulating layer on surface over time (prevents flame sensing)

Approved Igniters:

Honeywell approved only Norton 201 and 271 because they meet specifications:
- Reach 1000°C (1832°F) within 36s with 102V AC applied
- Maintain at least 500 MΩ insulation resistance between igniter lead wires and mounting bracket
- Current draw at 132V AC does not exceed 5A

Integrated Control Module (IFC) Testing:

Microprocessor control continually monitors appliance operation. When error occurs: Communicates fault analysis via fault LEDs or code displayed on user interface.

Fault Code Retrieval:

Not all IFC have fault code retrieval push button on module (FALSE - some use only LEDs, some have buttons).

Fault indication methods:
- Single LED with multiple flashes
- Multiple LEDs
- User interface display
- Combination of LED flashes and screen displays

Simple systems: Fault list shown right on module

Complex systems: LED flash code tables or multiple LED/screen display combinations

LED Flash Codes:

Can show:
- Normal status indicators (LED color changes)
- Fault conditions (specific flash patterns)
- Example: Variable-speed fully modulating furnaces use LED flashes AND user interface display

Multiple LED Systems:

More complex appliances may have:
- Multiple LEDs showing different system aspects
- Multiple screen displays
- Comprehensive fault tables with cross-referencing

Component Recalibration and Replacement:

Most controls factory-set or set upon installation per manufacturer instructions.

Never disturb settings unless definitely determined malfunction due to improper setting.

Thermostats: Example of control that CAN be recalibrated or readjusted (TRUE).

Other examples: Heat anticipators, oven thermostats, improperly operating gas valves, spark ignition electrode gaps, some pilots, some solid-state elements.

Most electronic controls: Cannot be field calibrated, must be returned to manufacturer or replaced.

Replacement Decisions:

Field repair often not practical. Often cheaper and safer to replace than repair.

Most electronic controls: Not repairable, must be replaced.

If module needs replacement:
- Ensure manufacturer-approved matching component
- Compare to existing unit to ensure connections match
- Label all wires before disconnecting
- Take picture for reference
- Check DIP switch settings on new module to match old one

Replacement Options:

Like-for-like: Simplest but component may be outdated, difficult to locate

Universal component: Can keep supply in van, become familiar with installation/operation, increase efficiency

Upgrade control system: More expensive initially but saves money long-run, benefits from current safety standards and technology

CSA B149.1 Requirements:

Clause 4.3.4 covers field acceptance of:
- Ignition systems (e.g., standing pilot to automatic ignition)
- Automatic safety shut-off valves
- Pilot-operated safety shut-off valves
- Miscellaneous requirements

Selection based on:
- Purpose of operation
- Sequence of operations
- Mechanical characteristics
- Electrical characteristics (switching actions, amperage ratings)
- Differential settings
- Physical dimensions (mounting, size)
- Resets (manual or automatic)
- Availability

Always consult manufacturer for approved replacement to ensure proper and safe operation.

Describe control concepts and components used in gas-fired appliances
Explain the basic control system and its four main sections
Identify and test operating controllers including thermostats, aquastats, and pressuretrols
Understand electronic sensors and their applications in modern control systems
Describe limit and safety controllers and their critical safety functions
Explain combustion safety controls and flame sensing technologies
Understand ignition control modules and their sequences of operation
Read and interpret wiring diagrams and schematic drawings
Test and troubleshoot control circuits systematically
Perform component servicing and replacement procedures safely
Assessment Breakdown
Required Resources
Textbooks

CSA Unit 12: Basic Electricity for Gas-Fired Equipment (reference)
Equipment/Tools
Digital multimeters
Manometers
Various control components for identification

Wiring diagrams and schematic collections
Safety Equipment
Personal protective equipment (PPE)

Insulated tools
Safety Considerations
WARNING: This course involves working with electrical systems and gas equipment. Students must:
Follow all safety procedures and use appropriate PPE
Never work on live circuits without proper authorization and supervision
Comply with CSA Z462 electrical safety standards
Understand lockout/tagout procedures before beginning any practical work

CSA Unit 13 Controls - Multiple Choice Exam (120 Questions)
Instructions
Choose the best answer for each question.
1. What is an algorithm in the context of gas controls? A) A mechanical switching device B) A set of electronic instructions pre-programmed into the microprocessor of an electronic controller C) A type of pressure sensor D) A manual reset button
2. Which signal type consists of only zeroes and ones? A) Analogue signal B) Digital signal C) Thermoelectric signal D) Pneumatic signal
3. What does BMS stand for in building control systems? A) Basic Monitoring System B) Building Management System C) Burner Management System D) Battery Management System
4. What is the flame failure response time? A) The time it takes for the main burner to ignite B) The time allowed to establish ignition C) The time it takes for flame sensor circuits to react to flame failure and de-energize the main gas valve D) The time required for manual reset after lockout
5. In the trial for ignition period, what happens if ignition is not established? A) The system continues trying indefinitely B) The system goes into lockout C) The gas valve opens wider D) The thermostat resets automatically
6. What principle do temperature snap discs operate on? A) Electromagnetic induction B) Thermal expansion causing shape change from concave to convex C) Gas pressure variation D) Liquid level detection
7. How do bimetallic strips work? A) They use the same expansion rate for all metals B) They use the warping action created when two dissimilar metals with different coefficients of expansion are welded together C) They operate on gas pressure changes D) They function through electrical resistance changes
8. What metal is used in the rod and tube control device for its low expansion/contraction rate? A) Copper B) Steel C) Invar D) Aluminum
9. What is the typical temperature limit for fluid-filled sealed bellows thermostats? A) 200°F (93°C) B) 650°F (343°C) C) 1000°F (538°C) D) 1648°F (900°C)
10. For high temperature applications reaching 3000°F (1648°C), what substance is used in pilot safety controls? A) Light oil B) Water C) Mercury D) Glycol
11. What happens when an electrical current passes through a metal conductor? A) The metal becomes magnetized permanently B) A magnetic field surrounds the conductor C) The metal expands D) The metal changes color
12. What is the typical voltage output of a single thermocouple? A) 120-240 volts B) 24-48 volts C) 1-5 volts D) 20-30 millivolts
13. What device is created by placing multiple thermocouples in series? A) Thermopile B) Thermostat C) Thermal relay D) Temperature switch
14. In a Wheatstone bridge circuit, when is the circuit in balance? A) When all resistors have equal value B) When the ratio of R1 to R2 equals the ratio of R3 to R4 C) When current flows between points A and B D) When the temperature exceeds setpoint
15. What type of electronic devices are made up of solid components that do not move? A) Electromechanical devices B) Pneumatic devices C) Solid-state devices D) Hydraulic devices
16. What happens when a small voltage is applied to the base of a transistor? A) It blocks all current flow B) It allows current to flow from collector to emitter C) It increases the voltage output D) It decreases the temperature
17. In which direction does a diode allow current to pass? A) In both directions equally B) Only from cathode to anode C) Only from anode to cathode (forward biased) D) It blocks all current flow
18. How do PTC thermistors respond to temperature increases? A) Resistance decreases B) Resistance increases C) Resistance stays the same D) They stop conducting entirely
19. How do NTC thermistors respond to temperature increases? A) Resistance increases B) Resistance decreases C) Resistance stays the same D) They become permanently damaged
20. What are the four basic sections of a control system? A) Power, Control, Safety, Ignition B) Operating Controllers, Limit and Safety Controllers, Combustion Safety Control, Ignition Control Module C) Input, Processing, Output, Feedback D) Mechanical, Electrical, Electronic, Pneumatic
21. What is the primary function of operating controllers? A) Monitor flame presence B) Respond to changes in the controlled variable and make or break a circuit C) Provide ignition timing D) Control gas pressure
22. What is the difference between electromechanical and electronic operating controllers? A) Electronic controllers are slower to respond B) Electromechanical controllers respond by making/breaking circuits, while sensors monitor variables for electronic controllers C) There is no functional difference D) Electronic controllers only work with DC power
23. What type of sensor do digital thermostats typically use to measure temperature? A) Bimetallic strip B) Mercury bulb C) Thermistor D) Thermocouple
24. What are the three typical power sources for digital thermostats? A) AC only, DC only, Battery only B) 24V AC with battery backup, rechargeable battery, or non-rechargeable battery C) Solar, wind, or hydroelectric D) 120V AC, 240V AC, or 24V DC
25. What is temperature swing in thermostat operation? A) The speed at which temperature changes B) The difference between the highest and lowest temperatures obtained in a room C) The time between heating cycles D) The accuracy of temperature measurement
26. What is the purpose of a heat anticipator in mechanical thermostats? A) To increase the temperature setting B) To cut off the furnace early and reduce system overshoot C) To prevent the thermostat from working D) To increase the gas pressure
27. What does CPH stand for in digital thermostat programming? A) Cycles Per Hour B) Comfort Per Hour C) Control Per Hour D) Current Per Hour
28. What is the typical CPH setting for high-efficiency condensing furnaces? A) 6 CPH B) 9 CPH C) 3 CPH D) 12 CPH
29. In a two-stage furnace system, what is typically the capacity of the first stage? A) 50% capacity B) 65% capacity C) 75% capacity D) 100% capacity
30. What should be the height placement for thermostats? A) 3 feet from the floor B) 7 feet from the floor C) Approximately 5 feet from the floor D) At ceiling level
31. What wireless protocols do wireless thermostats commonly use? A) Wi-Fi and Bluetooth B) Z-Wave and Zigbee C) Radio and infrared D) Satellite and cellular
32. What is the typical operating temperature for hydronic space heating systems with conventional boilers? A) 120°F (49°C) B) 140°F (60°C) C) 160°F (71°C) D) 180°F (82°C)
33. How do electromechanical aquastats operate? A) Using electronic sensors B) Using sealed bellows on the liquid expansion principle C) Using bimetallic strips D) Using thermistors
34. What is the typical differential range for adjustable aquastats? A) 1°F to 5°F (0.5°C to 3°C) B) 5°F to 30°F (3°C to 17°C) C) 30°F to 50°F (17°C to 28°C) D) 50°F to 100°F (28°C to 56°C)
35. What type of control is a pressuretrol? A) Temperature control B) Pressure activated switch C) Flow control device D) Level control switch
36. What is the main setting on a pressuretrol? A) Cut-in pressure when contacts close B) Cut-out pressure when contacts open C) Maximum operating pressure D) Minimum operating pressure
37. What are pressure transmitters used for? A) To increase gas pressure B) To convert applied pressure into a measurable electrical signal C) To reduce water pressure D) To control temperature
38. What are the two primary control concepts for system control? A) Manual and automatic B) On/off control and closed-loop control C) Mechanical and electrical D) High and low pressure
39. What is the main limitation of on/off control systems? A) They are too expensive B) They create temperature swings over and under the desired setpoint (deadband) C) They use too much energy D) They are unreliable
40. What does PID stand for in control algorithms? A) Pressure-Induced Differential B) Proportional-Integral-Derivative C) Primary-Intermediate-Direct D) Pneumatic-Input-Device
41. What is outdoor reset control? A) A manual reset button located outdoors B) When the controller calculates system water temperature setpoint by monitoring weather conditions C) A safety device that shuts down the system D) A method to test outdoor temperature sensors
42. What does BACnet stand for in building automation? A) Building Automation Control network B) Basic Automation and Control network C) Building Area Control network D) Burner Automation and Control network
43. What is the function of a low-water cut-off switch? A) To control water temperature B) To actuate in response to fluid movement and cut off power when water level falls below minimum C) To increase water pressure D) To filter water
44. What are the two basic types of low-water cut-off switches? A) Manual and automatic B) Float type and probe type C) High and low pressure D) Normally open and normally closed
45. What is the typical setting for a high limit aquastat? A) 150°F (66°C) B) 180°F (82°C) C) 200°F (93°C) D) 220°F (104°C)
46. What do flow switches respond to? A) Temperature changes B) Pressure changes C) Water movement D) Gas flow
47. What is a sail switch used to detect? A) Water flow B) Gas pressure C) Air movement D) Temperature changes
48. What is the typical setpoint for high-limit switches on forced warm-air furnaces? A) 150°F (66°C) B) 175°F (79°C) C) 200°F (93°C) D) 225°F (107°C)
49. When are gas-pressure switches required by code? A) On all gas appliances B) On burner systems operating with gas pressures greater than 1/2 psig (3.5 kPa) C) Only on commercial equipment D) On systems using propane gas
50. How do low gas-pressure switches operate? A) They open when gas pressure exceeds setpoint B) They are reverse acting and open if gas pressure falls below the setpoint C) They only work with natural gas D) They require manual reset
51. What is the basic purpose of combustion safety controls? A) To increase efficiency B) To safely operate the appliance under safe conditions C) To reduce emissions D) To save e

CSA Unit 13 : Controls
Chapter 1                  
Fundamentals of Controls
A gas technician/fitter regularly encounters numerous types of controls. 
The fundamentals of operating these controls are also numerous. 
Knowing how controls work, where they are applied, and how they 
interact with other controls is important to understanding overall 
systems.
MK by Mike Kapin
Created
Copywrite 2025
Purpose and Objectives
Purpose
A gas technician/fitter regularly encounters numerous types of 
controls. The fundamentals of operating these controls are also 
numerous. Knowing how controls work, where they are applied, 
and how they interact with other controls is important to 
understanding overall systems.
Objectives
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
•
describe control concepts and components
•
explain the basic control system
•
describe operating controllers
•
describe electronic sensors and operating controllers
•
describe electronic control concepts
•
describe limit and safety controllers
•
describe combustion and safety controls
•
describe ignition control modules
•
describe integrated appliance control modules
•
describe building management systems and communication 
protocols
•
describe valves and regulators
Terminology in Gas Controls
Algorithm
A set of electronic instructions 
pre-programmed into the 
microprocessor of an electronic 
controller. The microprocessor 
uses the algorithm to perform 
calculations with converted 
digital data received from system 
sensors.
Analogue signal
Has an arrangement of values, 
which could be measuring 
temperature, pressure, humidity, 
flow, light levels, etc., over any 
given time period.
Digital signal
One of two values they are also called binary, as their information consists 
of nothing but zeroes and ones. Examples include open/closed, 
start/stop, on/off, yes/no.
More Control System 
Terminology
Building management 
system (BMS/BAS/EMS)
The main building HVAC and 
energy control system designed 
to maximize energy 
performance as well as provide 
an optimal environment to the 
occupants in the area. The BMS 
uses a main network to connect 
to multiple areas or system 
controllers.
Direct digital control 
(DDC)
A term used in building 
automation for the concept of 
reading sensor data, processing 
the data in the digital domain, 
and controlling heating, 
ventilation, and air conditioning 
(HVAC) equipment. A DDC 
controller converts analogue 
signals to digital and back as 
needed.
Dual in-line package switch (DIP switch)
A manual electric switch that is packaged with others in a group.
Flame Control Terminology
1
Flame failure response time
The time it takes for the flame sensor circuits to react to a flame failure 
and de-energize the main gas valve.
2
Flame safeguard control (FSG)
The central controller over the safe supply of gas and air to the 
burner(s).
3
Trial for ignition
The period of time allowed to establish ignition. For modules that are 
part of a 100% safe system, the trial for ignition period is stated on the 
module.
4
Lockout
The expiration of the ignition time with a control module, which then 
requires a manual reset to restart the ignition sequence.
Network and Communication 
Terminology
Input/Output (I/O)
Commonly used to refer to the different signals or control points connected to the 
controller. The reference to I/O lets an installer know there are field connections 
required.
Local area network (LAN)
A network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a residence, 
school, laboratory, university campus, and office building.
Local operating network (LON)
A networking platform specifically created to address the needs of control 
applications, built on a protocol for networking devices over media.
Network protocols
A set of rules and conventions for communication between network devices. 
Standardized network protocols provide a common language for network devices.
Wireless Communication Terminology
Wireless communication
The transfer of information or power 
between two or more points using 
radio waves.
Wireless local area network 
(WLAN)
A computer network that links two or 
more devices over a short distance 
using a wireless distribution method.
Wireless personal area 
network (WPAN)
A PAN carried over a low-powered, 
short distance wireless network 
technology.
Wide-area network (WAN)
Any telecommunications network or 
computer network that extends over 
a large geographical distance.
Control Concepts: Thermal Expansion of Solids
Principles of Thermal Expansion
Control systems used in the gas industry use the physical characteristics of solids, liquids, and 
gases to expand and contract and to conduct or resist electricity as a means of regulating the 
burner system. For example, physical characteristics associated with the expansion of solids and 
liquids, electromagnetism, the thermoelectric effect, and electricity are all used in varying 
capacities.
Metals expand when heated and contract when cooled. The principle of the thermal expansion of 
solids is used for several control devices that regulate temperature change.
Temperature Disc
The temperature snap disc (Klixon®) responds to temperature changes by moving from a 
concave to convex shape, touching electrical contacts and completing a circuit. The temperature 
disc can be used in the thermal relay.
Bimetallic Strip Operation
How Bimetallic Strips Work
The bimetallic strip operates on the fact 
that not all metals expand at the same 
rate. This device uses the warping 
action created when two dissimilar 
metals having different coefficients of 
expansion are welded together at one 
end and exposed to temperature 
change.
Movement Mechanism
Since one end of the bimetallic strip is 
anchored solidly, the free end moves up 
or down with an increase or decrease in 
temperature. The resulting curling or 
bending is used to control the opening 
or closing of electrical contacts.
Applications
The functions of the bimetallic strip can 
be tied in with a change in voltage by 
wrapping a heat resistive wire around 
the strip. When voltage is applied, the 
current drawn by the wire will create 
heat, causing the bimetal to warp and 
open/close electrical contacts.
Rod and Tube Control Device
Construction
The rod and tube control device works on 
the principle that some metals expand 
more quickly than others. The sensing 
portion is constructed of copper tube that 
has a high expansion/contraction rate.
Components
The copper tube encases an invar rod, a 
metal alloy with a low 
expansion/contraction rate. The invar rod 
and copper tube are welded together at the 
far end.
Operation
The expansion and contraction of the 
copper tube effectively moves the invar rod 
back and forth, opening and closing a 
switch.
Thermal Expansion of Liquids
Liquid Expansion Principle
Like solids, liquids expand when 
heated and contract when cooled. 
When liquid is sealed in a narrow 
tube (called a capillary), the force 
created by the liquid expanding 
within the capillary is used to 
operate an electrical switch or 
control mechanism.
Sealed Bellows
In the sealed bellows control device, 
liquid inside a bulb at one end of the 
capillary tube senses the 
temperature of the surrounding 
atmosphere and expands or 
contracts. At the other end of the 
capillary tube an attached bellows 
reacts to the pressure within the 
capillary by expanding or 
contracting.
Applications
The action of the bellows is used to 
operate a switching device 
completing or interrupting an 
electrical circuit, or a mechanism 
that controls the gas valve outlet 
modulating the gas supply to the 
main burner.
Liquid Fill Types for Sealed Bellows
Fluid Fill
Sealed bellows used to operate thermostats may have a 
temperature limit of 650°F (343°C) and usually contain a 
fluid similar to a light oil. The expansion or contraction of 
this type of fill is quite linear and gives a smooth operation of 
the thermostat.
Always check the manufacturer's specification for 
recommended temperature and pressure limits.
Mercury
For high temperatures, such as 3000°F (1648°C) reached in 
pilot safety controls, the bulb must be filled with mercury. 
The expansion of the mercury is smooth up to 
approximately 650°F (343°C), at which point the mercury 
vaporizes (boils).
With vapourization, a rapid expansion takes place, giving 
the control "snap action". Similarly, upon cooling, there is a 
rapid contraction as the vapour condenses to a liquid.
Electro-magnetism in Controls
Electromagnetic Principle
When an electrical current is passed through a metal rod (conductor), a magnetic field surrounds 
the conductor.
Solenoid Creation
This principle has been used in creating the electromagnet, which forms the basis for the 
solenoid used in many control devices.
Solenoid Operation
When current runs through the solenoid coil, it creates a magnetic force that 
pulls the armature into the center of the coil.
Return Mechanism
When the circuit is opened, the magnetic field dies, and the armature 
returns to its original position, often with the assistance of a spring.
Thermoelectric Effect
Thermoelectric Principle
The thermoelectric effect of producing electricity by heat is used for the thermocouple and thermopile.
Thermocouple Construction
A thermocouple consists of a bimetallic strip joined at one end (called the hot junction).
Voltage Generation
When the hot junction is heated, a direct current (DC) voltage is 
generated across to the other two ends of the strips (the cold 
junction).
The thermocouple is used to prove the pilot flame. If it goes out, the thermocouple prevents the main gas valve from opening. The 
magnitude of the voltage across to the cold junction depends on the two materials of the bimetallic strip and the temperature difference 
between the hot and cold junctions.
Thermocouple Output and 
Applications
Thermocouple 
Output
The output of a single 
thermocouple is very small 
- 20 to 30 millivolts (mV) 
[1000 mV

Purpose
A gas technician/fitter regularly encounter numerous types of controls. The fundamentals of the operating these controls are also numerous. Knowing how controls work, where they are applied, and how they interact with other controls is important to understanding overall systems.

Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition

-
A set of electronic instructions pre-programmed into the microprocessor of an electronic controller. The microprocessor uses the algorithm to perform calculations with converted digital data received from system sensors.
Analogue signal
-
Has an arrangement of values, which could be measuring temperature, pressure, humidity, flow, light levels, etc., over any given time period

Modern control systems rely on sophisticated communication and management protocols. These terms define the digital infrastructure that enables advanced building automation.
Term
Abbreviation
Definition

BMS/BAS/EMS
The main building HVAC and energy control system designed to maximize energy performance as well as provide an optimal environment to the occupants in the area. The BMS uses a main network to connect to multiple areas or system controllers.
Digital signal
-
One of two values they are also called binary, as their information consists of nothing but zeroes and ones. Examples include open/closed, start/stop, on/off, yes/no. They can be used as indicators of equipment status, proof, safety, or limits.
Direct digital control
DDC

Advanced Control Terminology
Term
Abbreviation
Definition

-

Network Protocols
A set of rules and conventions for communication between network devices. Standardized network protocols provide a common language for network devices. Without them, computers wouldn't know how to engage with each other.
Personal Area Network (PAN)
A computer network for interconnecting devices that is catered on an individual person and can be used for communicating amongst the personal devices themselves or for connecting to a higher-level network
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Programmable logic controller
PLC
A type of controller that works based on the logic written by user (engineer); suitable for complex and high-level process applications and typically used for industrial applications as they have more programming capabilities than DDC
Sensor
-
Any devices, which could have analogue or digital signals that can measure some type of environment parameter or controlled variable and convert this parameter to a signal that the controller can understand
Setpoint
-
A state that a controlled system is aiming to reach (e.g., the temperature a thermostat has been set at)
Temperature and Safety Control Terms
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Thermistor
-
A device that changes its electrical resistance with a change in temperature
Thermostat
-
Device that can sense the temperature of the air or other media in a controlled area and translate this information into on/off switching of the heating or cooling equipment or modulation according to the demand
Trial for ignition
-
The period of time allowed to establish ignition. For modules that are part of a 100% safe system, the trial for ignition period is stated on the module.
Wide-area network
WAN
Any telecommunications network or computer network that extends over a large geographical distance. The internet could be considered the ultimate WAN as it is a global system of interconnected computer networks.
Modern thermostats incorporate advanced temperature sensing and control capabilities for precise environmental management.

Short-range wireless communication for personal devices

Low-power mesh networking for home automation
Wi-Fi (30–100 meters)
High-speed wireless networking for internet connectivity

CSA Unit 13 - Controls
Chapter 2
Electrical Control Systems for Gas-Fired Equipment
Master the fundamentals of electrical control systems used in gas-fired equipment. This comprehensive guide covers essential terminology, diagrams, components, and operational sequences that every gas technician must understand.
Essential Terminology
Electrical Symbols
Represent the switches and loads of a circuit in standardized visual format
Ladder Diagram
Same as schematic diagram - shows electrical flow in ladder-like format
Phasing
Matching the polarity of primary and secondary sides of a transformer
Polarity
Direction of current flow in DC circuits and differentiation between hot, neutral, and ground in AC circuits
The Foundation: Schematic Diagrams
The schematic diagram is the basic means of communicating the language of control. This essential tool consists of symbols interconnected by lines to indicate current flow through various devices.
Schematic diagrams reveal two critical elements:
The power source
How current flows through contacts, coils, and overloads
These diagrams focus purely on electrical operation without showing physical relationships between components.
Understanding Ladder Diagrams
Left-Hand Side
Represents the incoming voltage - the power source for the entire system
Right-Hand Side
Represents the outgoing current - each parallel load has a separate connection/rung
Ladder Rungs
Wires and devices connecting the two sides form the "rungs" representing separate circuits and components
Wiring Diagrams: The Circuit Map
Wiring diagrams are maps of electrical circuits that show exactly how and where wires connect between devices. They're invaluable for initial wiring and troubleshooting, displaying the actual location of all circuit components using standard electrical symbols.
Key Feature: All wires run horizontally or vertically. When wires cross, a dot indicates connection - no dot means wires cross but don't connect electrically.
Comparing Wiring vs. Schematic Diagrams
Wiring Diagram
Shows physical connections and component locations for installation and troubleshooting
Schematic Diagram
Shows electrical operation and current flow - much easier to follow the circuit logic
Circuit Types: Series and Parallel
Series Circuits
Components connected so electric current must pass through each one in sequence. Current has only one path to follow.
Parallel Circuits
More than one path is available for current flow. Components can operate independently of each other.
Series/Parallel Circuits
Complete electrical circuits may have some parts wired in series and others wired in parallel for optimal functionality.
International Electrical Symbols
Wiring and schematic diagrams use standardized symbols instead of pictures to represent switches and loads. These international symbols ensure universal understanding across the gas industry.
Key symbol categories include switches (disconnect, circuit breaker, limit, temperature, pressure), contacts, transformers, fuses, and wiring connections.
Switch Fundamentals
Normally Open (NO) Switches
Resting position is open. Typically used for actuating switches.
Symbol above line: closes on decrease in activating medium
Symbol below line: closes on increase in activating medium
Normally Closed (NC) Switches
Resting position is closed. Typically used for limit switches and safety controls.
Multiple Terminal Switches
Single Pole Double Throw (SPDT) switches can be wired as either NO or NC depending on the application. These versatile switches have three terminals but typically use only two.
Three terminal configuration showing common, NO, and NC connections
Wiring examples for both NO and NC configurations using common terminal
Relay Operation Principles
A relay is an automatically operated switch. In electric control systems, relays operate via electromagnet or solenoid, with electrical contacts opening/closing when the coil is energized or de-energized.
Common application: 24V coil controls 120V circuit, allowing safer low-voltage control wiring while switching higher voltage loads.
Relay Voltage Configurations
This diagram illustrates two different relay configurations:
CR1: 24V coil located in low-voltage circuit, contacts in 120V line voltage circuit
CR2: Both coil and contacts operate in line voltage circuits
This flexibility allows optimal safety and control design for various applications.
Relay Specifications and Ratings
Relay terminals are labeled to match the schematic stamped on the exterior. Contact ratings show maximum voltage/current the switch can repeatedly connect and interrupt without overheating or arcing.
Example NO contact ratings for 120V AC:
1 horsepower (HP)
16 Amps full load (AFL)
96 Amps lock rotor (ALR)
16 Ohms contact resistance
Time-Delay Relays (Timers)
Time-delay relays control equipment operation according to predetermined time intervals. They prevent simultaneous motor starting that could cause excessive current draw and blown fuses.
Common designations in ladder diagrams:
"TD" - Time Delay
"TDR" - Time Delay Relay
"TR" - Timer Relay
Arrows on contact symbols indicate time delay function.
Modern Control Integration
Most new equipment manufactured today includes integrated control boards that incorporate all necessary time-delay functions for equipment operation.
When coordinating multiple equipment starting and stopping, building automation strategies are implemented for optimal system performance.
Heavy-Duty Contactors
Heavy-duty contactors are solenoid/armature operators designed for switching high-current, high-voltage industrial equipment. The T-bar armature closes several contact sets simultaneously.
This example shows a three-phase motor contactor where a 110V solenoid circuit controls 240V three-phase lines to the motor.
Protective Devices: Fuses
Construction
Fuse element made of silver-tin alloy combining high conductivity of silver with low melting point of tin
Rating
Rated according to current value that may continually flow without causing element to overheat and melt
Time Characteristic
Inverse time characteristic - greater fault current results in faster circuit breaking
Circuit Breakers
Circuit breakers protect electrical conductors and equipment from overload and overcurrent effects, similar to fuses but with a key advantage.
Key Benefits:
Used in low-voltage distribution systems under 750V
Protect lighting and motor circuits
Can be reset by hand without replacing parts
Reusable protection device
Understanding Polarity in AC Circuits
01
Hot Wire
Any non-grounded conductor that carries current - typically black wire
02
Neutral Wire
Carries current when the circuit is closed - completes the electrical path
03
Ground Wire
Connected to ground, only carries current during short to ground - provides safety path
Determining Circuit Polarity
Step 1: Check Voltage Potential
Connect voltmeter across L1 and N (L2) at junction box to determine voltage potential between them
Step 2: Identify Hot and Neutral
Connect meter from each wire to ground - hot wire shows 120V AC, neutral shows 0V AC
Step 3: Verify Disconnect Operation
Check disconnect switch turns off power on hot lead - should read 0V AC to ground when off
Transformer Phasing Fundamentals
Matching the polarity of primary and secondary sides of a transformer becomes critical when the secondary side must be grounded, particularly with flame sensor circuits using flame rectification.
In Phase Configuration
Primary: 120V positive/negativeSecondary: 24V positive/negativeVoltage difference: 96V
Out of Phase Configuration
Primary and secondary sine waves oppositeVoltage difference: 144V
Checking Transformer Phasing
1
Connect Primary
Connect hot lead (L1) to black transformer lead, neutral (L2) to white transformer lead
2
Ground Secondary
Connect one side of transformer secondary to ground
3
Check Voltage
Measure between hot and ungrounded secondary side
4
Verify Phasing
96V reading = in phase144V reading = out of phase (move ground to other terminal)
Electrical Sequence Analysis
Gas technicians must determine operating sequences of gas appliances based on electrical circuitry provided by manufacturers. This requires solid grounding in reading wiring and schematic diagrams.
The ability to trace electrical circuitry is essential for understanding system operation, troubleshooting, and ensuring safe equipment function.
Residential Furnace Circuit Example
This residential warm-air furnace circuit demonstrates electrical sequence reading. The wiring diagram shows physical connections while the schematic (ladder diagram) reveals operational sequence.
Key principle: Switches connected to loads are normally located on the hot line, never in the neutral line.

Door switch and limit switch closed, 120/24V transformer powered
02
Heat Call
Thermostat calls for heat, thermostat switch closes
03

Furnace relay coil powered, contacts close, induced blower motor starts
04

Induced blower operation closes air proving switch, powers control module
05

Control module confirms no existing flame before ignition sequence
Ignition and Firing Sequence
Ignition Start
Igniter and pilot valve powered simultaneously for safe lighting
Pilot Proving
Pilot flame proven through flame sensor before main valve operation
Main Firing
Main valve powered, igniter de-energized, main burner fires
Fan Operation
Temperature rise closes fan control, circulating blower starts

CSA Unit 13
Fundamentals of Controls
Chapter 1
Created by LARK Labs
Overview
Purpose
A gas technician/fitter regularly encounter numerous types of controls. The fundamentals of the operating these controls are also numerous. Knowing how controls work, where they are applied, and how they interact with other controls is important to understanding overall systems.
Objectives
At the end of this chapter, you will be able to:
describe control concepts and components
explain the basic control system
describe operating controllers
describe electronic sensors and operating controllers
describe electronic control concepts
describe limit and safety controllers
describe combustion and safety controls
describe ignition control modules
describe integrated appliance control modules
describe building management systems and communication protocols
describe valves and regulators
Terminology
Understanding key terminology is essential for mastering control systems. The following definitions provide the foundation for comprehending how various control components operate and interact.
Term
Abbreviation (Symbol)
Definition
Algorithm
-
A set of electronic instructions pre-programmed into the microprocessor of an electronic controller. The microprocessor uses the algorithm to perform calculations with converted digital data received from system sensors.
Analogue signal
-
Has an arrangement of values, which could be measuring temperature, pressure, humidity, flow, light levels, etc., over any given time period
Control System Terminology
Modern control systems rely on sophisticated communication and management protocols. These terms define the digital infrastructure that enables advanced building automation.
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Building management system, building automation system, or energy management systems
BMS/BAS/EMS
The main building HVAC and energy control system designed to maximize energy performance as well as provide an optimal environment to the occupants in the area. The BMS uses a main network to connect to multiple areas or system controllers.
Digital signal
-
One of two values they are also called binary, as their information consists of nothing but zeroes and ones. Examples include open/closed, start/stop, on/off, yes/no. They can be used as indicators of equipment status, proof, safety, or limits.
Direct digital control
DDC
A term used in building automation for the concept of reading sensor data, processing the data in the digital domain, and controlling heating, ventilation, and air conditioning (HVAC) equipment
Advanced Control Terminology
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Dual in-line package switch
DIP switch
A manual electric switch that is packaged with others in a group
Flame failure response time
-
The time it takes for the flame sensor circuits to react to a flame failure and de-energize the main gas valve
Flame safeguard control
FSG
The central controller over the safe supply of gas and air to the burner(s)
Input/output
I/O
Commonly used to refer to the different signals or control points connected to the controller
Local area network
LAN
A network that interconnects computers within a limited area such as a residence, school, laboratory, university campus, and office building
Network and Communication Terms
Local Operating Network (LON)
A networking platform specifically created to address the needs of control applications, built on a protocol for networking devices over media (e.g., twisted pair, powerlines, fibre optics, and radio frequency), and used for the automation of various functions within buildings such as lighting and HVAC
Network Protocols
A set of rules and conventions for communication between network devices. Standardized network protocols provide a common language for network devices. Without them, computers wouldn't know how to engage with each other.
Personal Area Network (PAN)
A computer network for interconnecting devices that is catered on an individual person and can be used for communicating amongst the personal devices themselves or for connecting to a higher-level network
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Programmable logic controller
PLC
A type of controller that works based on the logic written by user (engineer); suitable for complex and high-level process applications and typically used for industrial applications as they have more programming capabilities than DDC
Sensor
-
Any devices, which could have analogue or digital signals that can measure some type of environment parameter or controlled variable and convert this parameter to a signal that the controller can understand
Setpoint
-
A state that a controlled system is aiming to reach (e.g., the temperature a thermostat has been set at)
Temperature and Safety Control Terms
Term
Abbreviation
Definition
Thermistor
-
A device that changes its electrical resistance with a change in temperature
Thermostat
-
Device that can sense the temperature of the air or other media in a controlled area and translate this information into on/off switching of the heating or cooling equipment or modulation according to the demand
Trial for ignition
-
The period of time allowed to establish ignition. For modules that are part of a 100% safe system, the trial for ignition period is stated on the module.
Wide-area network
WAN
Any telecommunications network or computer network that extends over a large geographical distance. The internet could be considered the ultimate WAN as it is a global system of interconnected computer networks.
Modern thermostats incorporate advanced temperature sensing and control capabilities for precise environmental management.
Wireless Communication Technologies
Bluetooth (2–10 meters)
Short-range wireless communication for personal devices
Zigbee (10–20 meters)
Low-power mesh networking for home automation
Wi-Fi (30–100 meters)
High-speed wireless networking for internet connectivity
Control Concepts and Components
Control systems used in the gas industry use the physical characteristics of solids, liquids, and gases to expand and contract and to conduct or resist electricity as a means of regulating the burner system. For example, physical characteristics associated with the expansion of solids and liquids, electromagnetism, the thermoelectric effect, and electricity are all used in varying capacities.
Each of the founding principles is discussed below, with examples of controls that operate on these principles.
Thermal Expansion
Utilizes the expansion and contraction of materials with temperature changes
Electromagnetism
Employs magnetic fields created by electrical current for mechanical action
Thermoelectric Effect
Converts temperature differences directly into electrical voltage
Electrical Resistance
Uses changes in electrical resistance to control system operation
Thermal Expansion of Solids
Metals expand when heated and contract when cooled. The principle of the thermal expansion of solids is used for several control devices that regulate temperature change.
Temperature Disc
The temperature snap disc (Klixon®) shown in Figure 1-1 responds to temperature changes by moving from a concave to convex shape, touching electrical contacts and completing a circuit. The temperature disc can be used in the thermal relay.
Figure 1-1 Temperature disc used in thermal relay
Bimetallic Strip
The bimetallic strip operates on the fact that not all metals expand at the same rate. This device uses the warping action created when two dissimilar metals having different coefficients of expansion are welded together at one end and exposed to temperature change.
Figure 1-2 Bimetallic strip warps and bends with an increase in temperature
Electrical Heating of a Resistive Element
Most materials conduct electrical current to some degree and heat up as a result. The amount of heat created depends on the material's electrical resistance and the amount of current flow through the material.
The functions of the bimetallic strip can be tied in with a change in voltage by wrapping a heat resistive wire around the strip. When voltage is applied, the current drawn by the wire will create heat, causing the bimetal to warp and open/close electrical contacts.
Rod and Tube
The rod and tube control device also works on the principle that some metals expand more quickly than others. In this control device, the sensing portion of the valve is constructed of copper tube that has a high expansion/contraction rate. The copper tube encases an invar rod, a metal alloy with a low expansion/contraction rate.
Thermal Expansion of Liquids
Like solids, liquids expand when heated and contract when cooled. When liquid is sealed in a narrow tube (called a capillary), the force created by the liquid expanding within the capillary is used to operate an electrical switch or control mechanism.
Sealed Bellows
In the sealed bellows control device, liquid inside a bulb at one end of the capillary tube senses the temperature of the surrounding atmosphere and expands or contracts. At the other end of the capillary tube an attached bellows reacts to the pressure within the capillary by expanding or contracting.
The action of the bellows is used to operate:
a switching device -- completing or interrupting an electrical circuit
a mechanism that controls the gas valve outlet modulating the gas supply to the main burner
The liquid in the bulb may be fluid fill or mercury, depending on the temperatures that will be encountered.
Fluid Fill
Sealed bellows used to operate thermostats may have a temperature limit of 650 °F (343 °C) and usually contain a fluid similar to a light oil. The expansion or contraction of this type of fill is quite linear and gives a smooth operation of the thermostat.
Always check the manufacturer's specification for recommended temperature and pressure limits.
Mercury
For high temperatures, such as 3000 °F (1648 °C) reached in pilot safety controls, the bulb must be filled with mercury. The expansion of the mercury is smooth up to approximately 650 °F (34

Operating pressure trans1nitter 
Industrial boilers may have remote electronic controllers that will require local sensors rather than 
electrometrical operating controls. Pressure transmitters or transducers convert an applied 
pressure into a measurable electrical signal. A pressure transmitter consists of two parts: 
• an elastic material, which deforms when exposed to a pressurized medium; and 
• an electrical device, which detects the deformation (Figure 1-32). 
One of the most common methods is to form the elastic material into a thin flexible diagram. The 
electrical device then detects this deformation and converts it into a proportional electrical signal.

The two primary control concepts are either: 
• on/off control used with electromechanical controllers; or 
Controls: Fundamentals

When electromechanical devices measure the controlled variables (air temperature, water 
temperature, etc.), they directly act upon a set of electrical contacts. For this reason, they were 
called controllers as they would be installed directly into an electrical circuit that would be 
energizing or de-energizing a load or relay. Therefore, the control sequencing and logic is built 
into the circuitry. This type of control concept is often referred to as ON/OFF control. On/off is a 
very simple form of control, but its outcome will have swings over and under the desired setpoint 
(deadband) (Figure 1-33). This is due to a number of reasons such as the equipment is only 
running at either 100% on or off, and the electromechanical controller itself has to have a 
differential designed into it or the contacts would be rapid firing constantly.

(e.g., indoor air). This enables a heating system to modulate its input and more closely match the 
load requirement to avoid the overshoot and undershoot inherent with an on/off control system.

Feedback 
When the controller receives feedback from the sensors, it compares the information with the 
setpoint value and makes adjustments. For example, the boiler may modulate its firing rate to 
better match the demand. The adjustments that the controller makes are based on a stored set of 
instructions (algorithm). One of the most common control processing algorithms used is called 
proportional-integral-derivative control (PIO). The algorithm continually examines the difference 
between the target value of the controlled variable and the measure value. This difference is 
referred to as error. 
September 2020 
41
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 13 
Controls: Fundamentals 
The PIO logic uses three distinct mathematical concepts to adjust its output signal: 
• Proportional response is when the output varies in proportion to how much error exists (e.g., 
how far is the boiler water temperature from the setpoint). 
• Integral response examines the duration over which the error occurs (e.g., how long has the 
temperature been below the setpoint). 
• Derivative response measures how fast the error is changing. This adjusts the reaction time. 
Outdoor reset 
In the examples above, the boiler firing rate is being modulated for more accurate control. Water 
temperature can also be adjusted to change the output of the heat emitters. Outdoor reset is 
when the controller calculates the system water temperature setpoint by monitoring weather 
conditions, as shown in the first two blocks of Figure 1-35. The controller lowers boiler water 
temperature when the outdoor temperature is warmer and increases it when the outdoor 
temperature is colder. This feature is included in the controller for most modern condensing 
boilers and, in many areas, is a regulated energy conservation requirement. 
Building management systems 
Today, many gas appliances have an integrate control located right on the equipment. These may 
include sensor (1/0) connections, as well as internal PIO modules within the control board. On 
larger commercial, institutional, and industrial systems, the control loop for the gas equipment is 
only one piece of the puzzle, and it needs to be able to work in harmony with other HVAC 
equipment. On these systems, it is common to use a DOC or PLC system to communicate, 
operate, and coordinate the various HVAC equipment. The building will likely have other control 
loops operating lighting, security, or other mechanical systems. When all the systems are tied into 
the building's main network (Primary Bus), this is referred to as a building management system 
(BMS), building automation system (BAS), or energy management systems (EMS) (Figure 1-35). 
This type of system gives operators and managers the ability to monitor and control remotely 
from any networked location. Connecting all the systems to one BMS can improve occupant 
comfort, system efficiency, energy consumption, and life cycle of equipment. The communication 
protocols used by various equipment controllers may be proprietary or open protocol language. 
Some examples of protocols used for Local Area Networks (LAN) include Ethernet, Building 
Automation and Control Network (BACnet), local operating network (LonWorks), Modbus, and 
KNX.

Building management systems may use the DOC or PLC to control the equipment firing rate and 
the outdoor reset functions. In these cases, it may be necessary to override these functions 
within the appliance's internal controller, which could entail specific settings on the appliance DIP 
switches and 1/0 connections as well as a network protocol interface module. 
Be sure to follow the manufactures instructions for setting up the appliance onto a BMS. 
Limit and safety controllers 
Limit and safety controls include all the interlocking controls to ensure that the burner cannot 
operate unless all associated functions to the burner are normal. Thus, in addition to the standard 
pressure and temperature safety limit controls used for the protection of the fired equipment, 
there are several other controls used as limits or interlocks. 
Low-water cut-off switch 
The low-water cut-off switch actuates in response to fluid movement. If the water level in the 
boiler falls below the minimum level, the low-water cut-off switch opens its contacts and cuts off 
power to the main gas valve. The Boiler and Pressure Vessel code lists when and where low 
water cut-offs are required. 
There are two basic types of low-water cut-off switches: 
• float type; and 
• probe type.

The float type (Figure 1-36) is a normally open switch that is held close by the float on top of the 
water. If the water level falls below a predetermined point, the float mechanism lowers and breaks 
the electrical contact.

Autornatic gas valves 
The automatic gas valve starts and stops the flow of gas to the appliance main burners. A 
sensing device activates the automatic gas valve, allowing the gas to flow to the burners where 
ignition will take place. There are many types of automatic gas valves with various sensing 
devices and activation methods. 
The methods of operation include: 
• Mechanically (non-electric) operated by a mechanical sensing device such as a capillary or 
rod and tube acting directly as the valve operator; and 
• Electromagnetic solenoid-operated where the control circuit is energized or de-energized to 
activate the valve. An electromechanical switch that contains a sensing device such as 
thermostat, aquastat, or pressuretrol can activate the control circuit. Alternately, an electronic 
control module that is monitoring the sensing device(s) could energize the control circuit, 
which is usually operated by 24 V AC, but may be by 120 V AC or millivoltage DC. 
Non-electric automatic gas valves 
Non-electric gas control valves rely upon a thermo-mechanical sensing element to act directly 
upon them. Two common types are: 
• rod and tube water heater gas valves; and 
• hydraulically operated gas valves. 
92 
September 2020
GAS TRADE TRAINING UNIT 13 
Controls: Fundamentals 
Rod and tube 
The rod and tube combination gas valve (Figure 1-90) is a multi-purpose valve typically installed 
in storage type water heaters. They are sometimes referred to as a Unitrol as this was one of the 
first most popular models used. It contains in one compact unit: 
• an automatic safety shut-off valve; 
• a main and standby gas cock; 
• a thermostat; 
• an automatic main gas valve; 
• an over temperature energy cut-off (eco) device; and 
• a main pressure regulator. 
Reset button

The Unitrol actuates in response to changes in water temperature. Its sensing device works on 
the rod and tube principle. In Figure 1-91, the copper tubes have been cut away to expose the 
invar rod, IJl(hich moves in and out of the valve body as the copper tube expands or contracts 
based on the temperature of the water it is immersed in. Notice the cutaway on the left has extra 
wires within the copper tube. This is a built-in safety device called an Energy Cut-Off (ECO). The 
ECO is a fusible link wired in series with the safety valve solenoid (Figure 1-91 ). If the 
temperature-sensitive fuse exceeds 200°F, the fuse will melt, and the electrical current to the 
safety valve power unit coil will be interrupted, shutting all of the gas off. Most ECOs are one-shot 
controls; if the ECO has tripped, the valve will have to be replaced.

More recent hot water gas valves for higher efficiency type water heaters with ventor motors 
require 120 V power and are direct-ignition. 
Modulating valve 
A modulating valve is a combination of two valves in a single unit designed to give precision 
temperature control with minimum cycling and maximum operating efficiency. This valve operates 
in a sequence as follows: 
• A snap-acting valve opens at the initial call for heat to provide the minimum rate of gas flow. If 
this gas flow is sufficient to bring the room up to the set temperature, the snap-acting valve 
closes. 
• If more heat is required, a modulating valve adjusts the gas flow rate between the fixed 
minimum and full burner capacity. 
• The valve is provided with a minimum rate that is intended to match the minimum gas flow 
requirement of the burner that it serves. 
The temperature-sensing bulb, capillary tubing, and bellows are filled with a temperature-
sensitive liquid. Changes in temperature at the bulb contract the liquid on temperature fall and 
expand it on temperature rise, causing the bellows to shorten and lengthen respectively. This 
movement is transmitted to the valve assembly by a horizontal pivot arm. 
The modulating valve shown in Figure 1-92 are also used for oven controls and liquid 
temperature controls.
